div.head: About This LEAP TEI P5 Customization
div.p: This TEI P5 ODD Customization was created by James Cummings with assistance from Adrian S. Wisnicki, with the initial prose based on the Livingstone Online's TEI P5 Tagging Guidelines written by Adrian S. Wisnicki and Heather F. Ball. The TEI P5 ODD is released under a Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial 3.0 Unported license.

div.head: Documentation Markup
div.p: In the prose of this documentation XML Elements, Attributes and Values appear as follows:

list.item: Elements appear marked as: persName (which is a link to its reference information) or /tagName (a tag fragment which is not a link to its reference information)

item.label: Blocks of original text appear as:
item.eg: the man turned out to be Livingstone

item.label: Blocks of marked up text appear as:
item.egXML: the man turned out to be Livingstone

div.p: (Note: the colors/formats are provided only to assist you in distinguishing between tags, attributes, and values. You do not need to change font colors in your transcriptions as you are transcribing. In general these colours mimic those found in the oxygen XML editor.)

item.p: When text is marked up, a tag is placed at the beginning of the text as well as at the end, per the following format: Original text: the man turned out to be Livingstone Marked up: the man turned out to be Livingstone
Note: that the first tag denotes the beginning of the marked up text, while the second tag begins with "/" and denotes the end of the marked up text.
If the opening tag includes an attribute, the attribute is NOT repeated in the closing tag: Original text: we were greeted by the Nyamwezi Marked up: we were greeted by the Nyamwezi
If there are two or more tags nested over one bit of text, the closing tags are placed in reverse order:
item.label: Original text:
Marked up:

item.p:
An attribute is always accompanied by a value, for instance:
Nyamwezi

If an opening tag ends with a "/", then it is an "empty element" combining the opening and closing tag and need not be used again at the end of whatever is being marked up. Original text: we saw the Lualaba Marked up:
we saw the Lualaba

Any problems related to the transcription should be addressed directly in the transcription at the points where they occur using the "comment out" feature. Original text: He called me over. Marked up: He called me over. In other words the commented out bit begins with <-- followed by a space and ends with -->. Always add your initials inside but at the end of the comment.

div.head: File Naming
div.p: When transcribing, please use the LEAP designated file name for the given item. This can be found on Livingstone Online along with the rest of the bibliographical data for the given item. So, for instance, Livingstone's letter to Rev. D.G. Watt (18 August 1850) would be: liv_000699.xml

If you are transcribing the given item with other individuals in sequence (and so the transcription is not yet final) please add your initials directly after the LEAP designated name: liv_000699_aw_hb_ks_hb.xml

In the above example, the four sets of intials indicate that the transcription has been worked on in four stages. The first three stages were done by three different individuals (aw, hb, ks) and the last stage was done by the second individual (hb).

The xml:id value on the TEI element of any LEAP file should be the initial parts of the LEAP designated file name without the '.xml' suffix. <?xml-model href="leap.rng" type="application/xml" schematypens="http://relaxng.org/ns/structure/1.0"?> <?xml-model href="leap.rng" type="application/xml" schematypens="http://purl.oclc.org/dsdl/schematron"?>

Please Note: All TEI P5 XML files are in the TEI Namespace which means their root element has a psuedo-attribute xmlns with a value of "http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0". This is the TEI Namespace and is inherited by any elements underneath keeps TEI elements safe from confusion with similarly-named elements from other schemes.

div.head: The TEI Header
div.p:
Each TEI file has a teiHeader element at the start which stores all the metadata for the electronic text. A sample full teiHeader element looks like:

Jared McDonald
Transcription Encoding

Adrian S. Wisnicki Coding review

Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial 3.0 Unported License . (c) Dr. Neil Imray Livingstone Wilson, 2011

Letters, 0229
Unknown Hand This hand is unknown but thought not David Livingstone's.
Letter to Rev. D.G. Watt, 18 August 1850 David Livingstone
18 August 1850
Kolobeng
Rev. D.F. Watt

That might look overwhelming, so let's break that down. Notice that there are really only a few elements directly inside teiHeader: fileDesc, profileDesc, and revisionDesc. Take a look at the header text above. You'll need to change some parts of this text (indicated in the comments) each time you start a new file in XML. Please copy the data exactly as found on Livingstone Online.

div.head: The TEI Header: Adding Title and Responsibilities
div.p: Once you have found the corresponding entry for the item you're transcribing on Livingstone Online, you will need to modify the template to match this information.
The item title should match the title found on Livingstone Online.

For each new person who works on the file, they should add a respStmt with an xml:id with their initials as the value. If a person has more than one responsibility the respStmt should have more than one resp element.
Letter to Rev. D.G. Watt, 18 August 1850 David Livingstone Adrian S. Wisnicki Christopher Lawrence
Jared McDonald
Transcription Encoding
Angela Aliff Transcription Encoding
Adrian S. Wisnicki Coding review
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: The TEI Header: Publication Statement
div.p:
Change the parts of the publicationStmt as needed:
Livingstone Online UCLA Digital Library Los Angeles, CA, USA
2015
liv_000688
All materials are licensed for use under the
Creative Commons Attribution-Noncommercial 3.0 Unported License . (c) Dr. Neil Imray Livingstone Wilson, 2011
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: The TEI Header: The Source Description
div.p:
The msDesc element must contain an msIdentifier where elements are given in a specific order from most general to most specific. First location elements like country and settlement, followed by institutional data like institution and/or repository, followed by an idno and any alternative identifiers altIdentifier, and finally a physDesc.
South Africa
Johannesburg
Brenthurst Library
778
Letters, 0229
Unknown Hand This hand is unknown but thought not David Livingstone's.
In this case a note of the hands in the manuscript is given in a handNote with an xml:id attribute that can be pointed to from additions or deletions in the text. See . More than one handNote can be recorded in the handDesc inside the physDesc element. The default assumption is that all writing is by David Livingstone so his hand need not be recorded.

After the closing /msDesc there is a bibl element containing a variety of source metadata. You must update the:
title (usually the same as in titleStmt)
date of composition (both the human readable content and the when attribute)
place of composition (if known, otherwise 'Unknown')
name of the addressee (if known, otherwise 'Unknown')
Letter to Rev. D.G. Watt, 18 August 1850 David Livingstone
18 August 1850
Kolobeng
Rev. D.F. Watt
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: The TEI Header: The Profile Description
div.p:
The profile description contains additional metadata about the file. In the case of LEAP files this is used to store the language(s) in the document. Usually this will just be English and so should not be changed.
English
However, multiple language elements can be provided if necessary and should have the proper ISO 639 language code for the language. See .
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: The TEI Header: The Revision Description
div.p:
A later part of the header, the revisionDesc, contains entries that record the major milestones of work completed on, or updates to, the file:
Initial transcription and XML encoding
When working from the encoding template, either change the information in this entry as relevant (if you are the first one working on the given item) or add a new iteration of this element above the previous one to record a new stage of devleopment. For each iteration, you need to change the the when attribute to the correct YYYY-MM-DD format. You need to change who attribute to have a value of your initials prefixed with a '#': #AW to match your initials. This URI fragment points to the respStmt you added above and records your responsibility in making this change. Finally, you need to provide the appropriate description of your work. A change element should only be provided at each major stage of file development.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Divisions of the Text
div.p: We use the div to contain the main body of text of any given Livingstone object, so in most cases a transcription will only have one div elment that opens and closes the text. However, there are some cases where a second div element should be used. See , , and .

div.head: Front and Back Matter
div.p: Use front and back elements (siblings of the body element) to contain to any material that, respectively, precedes (e.g., a table of contents) or succeeds (e.g. an appendix) the main text being encoded.

div.head: The Beginning of a New Page
div.p: After the initial textbodydiv tags (already in the diary template document), make sure there is a pb element at the beginning of each new page/image that you transcribe. Note that the manner in which this is based on the LEAP designated file name

Note that this combined or empty element ends with a "/" and has no separate closing tag. The facs attribute points to the image facsimile for this page, the n attribute records the project page number separately.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: The Beginning of a Manuscript Line
div.p:
Whenever you come to the beginning of a manuscript line, use
No corresponding tag is needed at the end of the line. Original text: As we traveled
I came
across two men. Marked up:
As we traveled
I came
across two men.

If line breaks occur in the middle of an addition, do not place lb/ before the first line of the addition, but do use it to mark the beginning of each subsequent line of the addition: First line of addition
second line,
and third line.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: The Beginning of a New Paragraph
div.p: When you start a new paragraph, use the following tag: p

The rend attribute is used to indicate information about the rendering of the paragraph as a whole in the original source. For example, if the paragraph as a whole was centered on the page, you might give it a value of "center" or if aligned right a value of "right". The use of rend to say whether something is centered or right (left is considered the default so there is no need to record that) is a bit of a judgment call regarding the placement of the paragraph on the page.
This paragraph is aligned to the right on the page.
For more information about the rend attribute see .
The default assumption is that a paragraph is indented, so there is no need to mark that. For marking the exceptionally indented first lines of paragraphs see .

However, if a paragraph is not indented, please mark it as follows:
This paragraph is not indented
Note: It is especially important to use p rend="no-indent" when marking new, dated diary entries that Livingstone begins on a new line but does not indent.
Also, remember at the end of the paragraph to use the closing paragraph tag /p.

Finally, note that we capitalize the first word of a new paragraph by default. If it is not capitalized, use the choice, sic, and corr tags to correct this.
arrivedArrived at the lake.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Dates
div.p:
For marking up dates use the date element with the when attribute. The value of the when attribute should always be given in this YYYY-MM-DD format (four-digit year, two-digit month, two-digit day). This is an important international standard for representing dates and stops people and computers getting confused as to whether '05/02/71' means the second of May or the fifth of February:
5th February 1871
If only the month and year (and not the day) are given, code as follows: We visited in February 1871 However, if the day (and month) are given, but not the year, yet you know the year provide it. For instance, if Livingstone begins a diary entry with "5th" but you know from previous entries that this actually means 5th February 1871, then code it as follows: We visited last year on the 5th If you don't know the year, bring it to the attention of the project and code it as follows: We visited on 5th February

Finally, use the from and to attributes to provide a start and end date of a range. Use these as needed:
5th to 7th February 1871
For B.C. dates code as follows: 28 March 600 B.C. or 600 B.C.
For coding dates that Livingstone adds to the margin of the Unyanyembe Journal, see .
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: The Opening and Closing of Letters
div.p:
Note that the opening and closing of letters often have items which aren't strictly paragraphs. The TEI has special elements just for these. The entire beginning of a letter should be contained within an opener tag. Within this opener tag, any address or date will also be contained within a single dateline. Finally, any personalized greeting, should go inside of a salute tag:
Hadley Green
22 August
1857
My Dear Sir,

Likewise, the end of a letter should be contained within a closer tag, with any personalized address contained within a salute tag and any signature within a signed tag.:
Sincerely,
David Livingstone
For both the opener and closer, linebreaks (see ) should be marked in the regular fashion, as in the examples above.

Definitions of the elements used above are:
The date and persName elements are discussed in more detail below.

div.head: Postal Address of Letter Recipient
div.p:
The portion of each letter that contains that postal address of the letter recipient should be placed inside both the closer and address elements. If the placement of the address within the letter does not allow for the address to be added to the closer, then place the address in a separate set of div and ab elements. Each line of the address should be marked with addrLine/. Note too that when you use addrLine/, you should not use lb/ (see ). In other words, use addrLine/ or lb/, but not both.
Bevan Braithwaite 3 New Court Lincoln's Inn

div.head: Postscripts
div.p:
Use the postscript element to contain the entirety of any postscript added to a letter. Each separate postscript should be contained by its own element. The n may be used to number successive postscripts.
P.S. Give my regards
to your children.
P.P.S. And greet your parents
Note: In order for your use of the postscript to validate, it may be necessary to place empty opener/ and closer/ tags before it, if you haven't already otherwise used such tags.

div.head: Any Type of Heading
div.p:
Use the head element for any type of heading, such as the title of a chapter or section or the heading of a list
Chapter I

div.head: Running Header (including Authorial Page Numbers)
div.p: Use the fw element to contain any type of running head (usually, but not always, found in the header or footnote of a given page) that appears on a page or series of pages. The rend may be used as needed to mark the location of this element. 1
For any page numbers instituted by Livingstone himself, use the fw element plus n in the following manner:

In other words, whenever fw is used to encode one of Livingstone's page numbers, n value should begin with "heading_" followed by the number Livingstone uses, in the form that he uses it (i.e., Roman or Arabic numeral).

div.head: Textual Formatting
div.p: If the original text is formatted in some manner such as underlining, superscript, etc., use the hi element with the rend attribute.
If there is more than one type of formatting, for instance both underline and superscript, use the rend attribute only once but provide two values separated by a space.

Please Note: The rend attribute is part of the att.global class and so can be used on other elements if they are present. For example instead of marking up: Lualaba
one can do: Lualaba
but if unsure then the former is acceptable.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Textual Colors
div.p: Livingstone occasionally changes the color of his text. In the majority of cases, such changes fall into one of two categories: a change in color for a few words; a change in color for a longer section of a text. Changes of the former sort (a few words) are usally due to an after-the-fact addition, so the color change should be marked with rend and the appropriate color directly on the add element: We followed the path

If Livingstone changes color for a longer section of text (this often happens in his field diaries), use the div element plus rend and the appropriate color to mark the different sections of the text:
First section in black would go here.
Second section in blue would go here.

Please note: Sometimes words appear to be the same color but are darker than their surrounding text. This may or may not be an intentional attempt by Livingstone to emphasize a portion of the text. To be on the safe side, code such darkening as appropriate. If it seems to be intentional, code it as follows with hi plus the appropriate color:
Mtarika came at last. If it seems to be unintentional, code it with seg plus the appropriate color:
They do not appear to have asked for the
names of places so much as for those of people

div.head: A Word Broken Up Over Two Lines
div.p: Use the w element to mark words that Livingstone breaks up over two lines. You also add the break attribute with the value of "no" to the lb/ that falls between the two halves of the word. For LEAP materials the assumed value for the break attribute is yes, so you do not need to provide this unless it is an exceptional circumstance. Use maybe only in those cases when you are not sure whether a single word apparently broken up over two lines may indeed be two words.
Livingstone's use of hyphens is erratic. Sometimes he hyphenates a word at the end of the first line, sometimes at the beginning of the second, sometimes in both places, sometimes in neither.
We code each of these instances in the same way, but we also always supply a hyphen at the end of the line if Livingstone himself has failed to provide it.

p.label: Example #1 (no hyphen at all)
p.egXML:
I look on the drove they brought un-
chained with a sort of pleasure after

p.label: Example #2 (hyphen only in first line)
p.egXML:
by one of Dugumbe's people after finish-
ing a piece of work = said he was tired

p.label: Example #3 (hyphen only in second line)
p.egXML:
sorely needed to be employed him-
-self in something else than penny

p.label: Example #4 (hyphen in both lines)
p.egXML:
by which the irresponsible con-
-clave brought the Indian command

div.p: Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: More Than One Space between Words
div.p:
If you are encoding text where the author has placed more than one space between words, do not insert additional space in your transcription. Rather insert only one space plus the following markup:
a word

In other words, in the example above the space being marked is actually five characters long. One of these spaces is marked in the normal fashion, the other four are marked with the space tag. Please follow this format when marking usual spacing between words.

The value for the extent attribute will of course be a bit of a judgment call, but a good rule of thumb is to mark only those spaces that extend for more than two characters and/or have some obvious, non-trivial significance in the text. For instance, Livingstone on occasion inserts an unusally large space just before a new sentence and indeed uses this space to indicate that the substance of the sentence that follows the space differs significantly from that of the sentence that precedes the space.

The value "chars" stands for "characters"; you can also use "words". There is a dim attribute on space with allowed values of horiztonal or vertical. The default assumption in LEAP is that extra space is horizontal so this does not need to be marked.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: One or More Spaces between Lines
div.p: If you are encoding text where the author has left extra spaces between lines, you can mark up the spaces in one of two ways:

If there is only one space between lines, only an extra lb/ tag is needed:
...and he arranges any
differences that may
arise -
Called at Mataka's house ...
If there is more than one space between lines, a space/ tag is used, along with the dim, extent, and unit attributes and their appropriate values.
...and he arranges any
differences that may
arise -
Called at Mataka's house ...
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Dividing Lines Across the Page
div.p: Livingstone often uses lines that he draws across the page to separate sections of the text. Sometimes he uses a single line that runs across the entire page from left to right; sometimes a double-line; sometimes a single line that only runs across half or a quarter of the page. For all such lines, use the milestone/ element in the following manner:

As in the example, milestone/ should always inlcude a unit attribute with the value of "section" and a rend attribute. Possible values for the rend attribute include: "line", "double-line", "triple-line", "half-line", and "quarter-line".

div.head: Textual Directions
div.p:
There are four possible situations we've encountered, so here's how to handle them:
The page text is upside-down. If it is upside-down for only a phrase or a few lines, use seg rend="upside-down" or some other relevant element to contain the text. If it runs upside-down for a larger amount of text, create a new div and mark the orientation there: div rend="upside-down".
The page text is horizontal, then it clearly continues to vertical text in the margin. Use cb plus rend with a value of vertical in either one of the two following ways (line numbering continues in the normal way):
If the vertical text in the margin is really a new paragraph then mark it as such by ending the current paragraph with /p at the end of the horizontal text, then start the vertical text with cb rend="vertical"/p and when you finish the vertical text close it with /p as normal.
If the vertical text in the margin continues the horizontal text without a paragraph break, do not end the paragraph but indicate the place where the text changes to vertical with a cb rend="vertical"/ element. When the paragraph ends mark it with a closing /p.
The page text is horizontal, but ends at the bottom of the page. You believe that the vertical text continues from the horizontal text, but it seems to be a new "section" (how you define section is a bit subjective). Then close the horizontal text as normal with /p/div. Begin the vertical text as a new division with div rend="vertical"p then when it is finished close the vertical text with /p/div and begin the next section with a new div tag. In other words, you're breaking this up into two sections (with one or more paragraphs inside) that you believe are continuous. Line numbering is continuous.
The page text is horizontal and may or may not end at the bottom of the page. The vertical text has no clear relationship to the horizontal text. End the page text with /p (whether or not it continues to the next page), then begin the vertical text with cb rend="vertical"ab and close the vertical text with /ab. Then on the next page, whether or not it's a new paragraph, begin with p, etc. Restart the line numbering in this new absection.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Text with No Clear Relationship to the Surrounding Text
div.p: Occasionally Livingstone includes blocks of text on a given manuscript page that have no clear relationship to the main text on that page. Such blocks should be encoded with the ab element.
Note that, as in the example above, you can use p or ab to enclose sections of text, but not both.

div.head: Addition to or Deletions from the Original Manuscript
div.p: If a portion of the text has been added by the author or someone else other than you (see above), use add to mark up that text. The place attribute has values of: "inline", "above", "below", "marginleft", "marginright", "margintop", "marginbottom". Original text: he saw us [in this case it's clear in the ms. that "saw" was added later] Marked up: he saw us

If a portion of the text has been deleted by the author or someone else, use del to mark up that text. Optinally, use the type attribute to indicate the type of deletion with values of "strikethrough" (deleted with a single line) or "cancelled" (deleted with multiple lines). Original text: he saw us Marked up:
he saw us
If the deletion makes the character(s) or word(s) being deleted impossible to read, use the gap element to indicate this:
Note: For coding additions and deletions that span more than a few lines of text, please consult the project team.

If it isn't a standalone addition or deletion but you believe a combined deletion and addition has been done (usually by the author) as a single intervention, then you may nest the del and add elements in a subst (substitution) element. Then we went towardsto the river
Livingstone often deletes a character or word by writing another character or word over it. For such instances use the following coding formula: He gavehanded it to me.
If such a substitution occurs in the middle of a word, you may use w to avoid confusion by indicating the beginning and end of the full word: He giave it to me.

When Livingstone uses a caret (^) to indicate the place of an addition, use a separate add tag for the caret and place a space between the tagged caret and the additional text that Livingstone has added: ^ a word

In both the cases of added or deleted text, if you believe that the work has been done by someone other than Livingstone but cannot identify who that person is, use the hand attribute with a value of "#U". he saw us The #U is a pointer to a handNote element (in a handDesc in a physDesc in the msDesc in the sourceDesc in the header).
Unknown Hand This hand is unknown but thought not David Livingstone's.
he saw us
If you can identify individual hands, but not to whom they belong, these values could be #hand01 or #hand02 or similar.

Finally, to denote any kind of arrow or other mark (other than a caret) that Livingstone uses to indicate where a bit of add or deleted text should go, use an empty metamark/ element. Then we went towards home.

Optional: In some cases, such as the manuscript of Livingstone's Missionary Travels, you may be working with more specialized metamarks. To code these, you can use the metamark/ tag plus the type attribute and any of the following values: insertion, deletion, transposition, and newParagraph:
However, such additional coding is not required and should only be done in consultation with the project team.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Authorial Notes within the Text
div.p: Use the note element anytime Livingstone himself inserts a note, gloss, or footnote outside the body of the main text that explains an item within the main text. the whole tribe x if it were necessary for me to seek a character I would confidently refer to the Bakwains for it

The note element combined place and the "marginleft" value should also be used to mark the dates that Livingstone periodically adds to the left margin of the Unyanyembe Journal. These should be marked as they occur, even if that happens in the middle of a sentence:
I was content
8th to take the canoe on any terms -
If the date added to the left margin spans more than one line, use lb/ as appropriate (see ):
div.egXML:
13th April
1866 alone but other nations feel

div.head: Authorial Punctuation and Capitalization
div.p: Livingstone limits his punctuation primarily to n-dashes (-), which often shade into m-dashes or even longer dashes, and equal signs (=). He distinctly prefers n-dashes, but he uses these interchangeably with equal signs in places of such punctuation as commas, colons, semicolons, and periods as well as to mark simple pauses in the text. When transcribing an n-dash or equal sign, please adhere to the following guidelines.
When Livingstone uses an n-dash for any reason other than hyphenation of a word, place a space before and after the n-dash when trascribing it, even if it looks like Livingstone himself hasn't:
Likewise, when transcribing an equal sign that Livingstone has used as punctuation, place a space before and after, even if it looks like Livingstone himself hasn't:

When Livingstone uses an n-dash to introduce or follow a quotation, he places the n-dash directly below the opening or closing quotation marks rather than next to them. However, when transcribing this, you should nonetheless put a space between the dash and the quotation mark:
div.eg: He said - "I will" - in answer to me.
div.p: If unsure, whether Livingstone is using a period or dash, select dash by default.
If Livingstone's n-dash looks like an m-dask or even longer, use two or more n-dashes without any space between them:
Livingstone also has a tendency to run the first person pronoun ("I") onto the following word, as in the following: "Iwent". All instances of this should be silently separated when transcribed:

Livingstone is by no means consistent in his use of capitalization and, moreover, it is often even not clear whether a word is capitalized or not. When transcribing, use the following rules of thumb. When a word is capitalized (or not) and the context suggests this is correct, transcribe as is. When a word is capitalized (or not) and the context suggests this is incorrect, transcribe as is but if (in your opinion) it is very important that the capitalization be corrected, use choice plus sic and corr to provide a corrected verison of the word:
div.egXML: The man spoke to me - thenThen he left.
div.p: For use of the choice, sic, and corr elements, see .
Finally, if it is not clear whether a word is capitalized and it would therefore be OK to transcribe it either way, allow context to guide your decision as to whether to capialize it or not.

div.head: Authorial Grammatical, Typographical, and Other Mistakes
div.p: When you encounter some sort of textual mistake made by the author, mark it with a combination of the choice element and both the sic (apparent error) and corr (correction) elements. Original text: I recieved your letter Marked up: I recievedreceived your letter

If there is an uncertainty as to the correction that you provide use the cert attribute with values of "low", "medium", "high" to denote the degree of confidence in the addition you have made: recievedreceived
If a duplicate word appears in the text, use the choice, sic, and corr elements to remove it: till the the astringent poison

Note: Livingstone tends to leave off apostrophes for contractions and possessives. To mark such instances in the text, do not use supplied plus an apostrophe, but rather code with choice plus sic and corr: dontdon't

Important Note: Be sure to remember that there is a difference between errors and variants. If Livingstone makes an obvious error, then use choice, sic, and corr, as described above. However, if Livingstone uses a variant that would not have been incorrect in his own day (e.g., Mosambique) and/or that exists in a more common, alternative form now (Mozambique), use choice, orig, and reg to normalize this (see ).
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Text that is Not Clear
div.p: Use unclear to mark up any text that is not clear; furthermore, use the cert attribute with values of "low", "medium", or "high" to denote the degree of confidence in the transcription you have made: he said he would say me tomorrow
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Variant Readings
div.p:
Use the app element plus at least two or more instances of the rdg element to mark valid alternate readings of a single word or textual passage. If needed, cert may be used with values of "low", "medium", "high" to denote the degree of confidence in a given reading.
willwell

div.head: Missing Portions of the Manuscript Page or Text that is Illegible
div.p:
We use gap to tag text that is wholly illegible due to deletion or some other factor, or missing all together from the manuscript page due to physical damage. The gap element never contains text:
sugar -- candles
In the gap element, the values we use for the agent attribute include: "blot", "fading", "hole", "illegible", "overwriting", and "stain".
The value of the extent attribute is always an approximation.
Note: For coding manuscript damage that spans more than a few lines of text, please consult the project team.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Portion of the Text that You Have Supplied
div.p: If a portion of the original text is missing for whatever reason and you supply it, use supplied to mark up this addition; furthermore, use the cert with values of "low", "medium", "high" to denote the degree of confidence in the addition you have made:

Important Note: You should be very conservative in your use of the supplied tag and only supply text of which you are 100% certain. Otherwise, use gap/. In other words, avoid guessing at Livingstone's meaning unnecessarily.
Note: The supplied tag is never nested in the gap tag. he saw the man
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Normalized Text
div.p: Use the choice element plus orig and reg to mark any instances where Livingstone's text, although not incorrect necessarily, is nonetheless normalized or otherwise corrected by you. shewshow
Note: this also includes the normalization of proper nouns: The SuaheliSwahili

div.head: The Ampersand and Other Special Characters
div.p: When you transcribe an ampersand, use & instead of an actual ampersand: Original text: I saw John & Jim Marked up: I saw John Jim

If you come across any other unusual characters that are not found within the "Insert from Character Map" option from the "Edit" dropdown menu in oXygen, add a comment to draw the attention of the project to this.

div.head: Quotation from Another Source
div.p: When dealing with a quotation from another source, usually a printed source (which may or may not be explicitly identified in Livingstone's text), use the quote element. As it is stated in the Bible, "Neither do men light a candle, and put it under a bushel...." Note: As in the example above, the quote element goes inside of the quotation marks that surround the given quotation. In other words, do not mark the quotation marks as part of the quotation.

div.head: Abbreviations
div.p: When you encounter an abbreviation made by the author, mark it with the choice element and both the abbr (abbreviation) and expan (expansion) elements. Original text: my no. 1 friend Marked up: my no.number 1 friend

If there is an uncertainty as to the expansion that you provide, use the cert attribute with values of "low", "medium", "high" to denote the degree of confidence in the expansion you have provided. my no.number
Please note: any prefix pertaining to a personal name, i.e. Dr, Mr, Miss, Rev, need not be expanded.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Fractions
div.p: We use choice and the orig and reg elements to encode fractions: 1/2
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Names of People
div.p: When marking up a person's name, use the persName element. I saw David Livingstone
However, note the following example: I saw Dr David Livingstone's tent

Please note: any prefix pertaining to a personal name, i.e. Dr, Mr, Miss, Rev, should be included within the persName element but and does not need to be expanded. Likewise any possessive marker ('s) can be outside the persName.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Place Names and Geographical Elements
div.p: When you mark up a geographical element, use the placeName element and one of the following: bloc (for multi-national entities like 'Africa'), country (for countries), region (for large administrative units), or settlement (for cities, towns, villages). On settlement use the type attribute to record values such as "city", "town", or "village". Nyangwe
Use geogName to denote a specific named geographical entity not covered by the above, using the type attribute with values such as "lake", "river", etc. Nile
You should also use geogName when encoding the full reference to a geographical entity that includes any kind of formal name (which itself would also be separately encoded:

If Livingstone refers to a specific, named geographical entity (and you know what that entity is), but uses only a generic term such as "the Lake" or "the River," you should identify this entity in a comment that directly follows the relevant term, but not otherwise mark the term used:
Note: Livingstone uses "Metamba" to reference the Central African rainforest, although the term is really a local word for "forest." To account for this usage, please code as follows:
Note: "Cape" and "Interior" should be coded with the region element (even though technically incorrect). Code "Zanzibar" as follows:
Directional words (North, South, East, and West) should not be tagged when referring to directions. Rather tag directional words only when Livingstone uses them to designate a region:
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Geographical Measurements
div.p: Use the measure element to mark any geographical quantities (including geographical coordinates) that Livingstone cites in the text. This includes distances measured in days or hours as well (most often used in reference to the party's marches). The village was a few days' march from here If Livingstone provides an obvious group of geographical quantities, an additional measure element should be used to encapsulate the group.
div.egXML: The river was 30 feet deep and 1000 yards across
div.p: Note: If Livingstone introduces a larger set of geographical coordinates, these should normally not be transcribed, but rather be noted with the figure and figDes elements. See .

div.head: References to Weather
div.p: Use seg type="weather" to mark passages in the text where Livingstone refers to the weather.
div.egXML: We have rain in large quantity almost every night
div.p: Such weather references may be loosely made, and it may be difficult to determine where exactly they begin and end. In all cases use the seg elment and best judgment to mark such references. Opt for one use of seg to mark a longer passage with a series of specific descriptions rather than multiple uses of the seg element.
Note: When Livingstone provides the outside temperature, this should be be coded with only seg type="weather", and not the measure element.

div.head: Animals (Including Fish), Insects, Plants, and Foodstuffs
div.p: When dealing with animals, including fish, use the term element with the type attribute with a value of "animal". The value of "animal" in the singular should be used in all cases, even when the text refers to multiple animals of one kind. Livingstone's uses of general terms such as "animal" or "beast" need not be tagged. elephants

When dealing with insects, use the term element with the type attribute with a value of "insect". The value of "insect" in the singular should be used in all cases, even when the text refers to multiple insects of one kind. Livingstone's uses of general terms such as "insects" or "bugs" need not be tagged. tetse

When dealing with specifically named plants, use the term element with the type attribute with a value of "plant". The value of "plant" in the singular should be used in all cases, even when the text refers to multiple plants of one kind. Livingstone's uses of general terms such as "trees", "bushes", or "grass" need not be tagged. Euphorbias

When dealing with foodstuffs, use the term element with the type attribute with a value of "foodstuff". The value of "foodstuff" in the singular should be used in all cases. Livingstone's uses of general terms such as "food" need not be tagged. bread

If Livingstone refers to a foodstuff that is also a plant, use the term element with the type attribute with the value of "plant_foodstuff" (in that order): maize This format should be used regardless of the state in which the given item appears in the text. coffee Beverages, both alcoholic and non-alcoholic, should be coded as foodstuff and follow previously stated formats. brandy
Note: Terms relating to meals (such as breakfast, lunch, supper) should not be coded as "foodstuff."

div.head: Nationalities
div.p: When dealing with nationalities, use the term element with the type attribute with a value of "nationality". the English settlements
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: People of a Given Nationality
div.p: When dealing with people of a given nationality (e.g., Englishmen, Americans), use the term element with the type attribute with a value of "people". Englishmen
If the reference is to just one person of a nationality (e.g., a Englishman, American), use the term element with the type attribute with a value of "person". Englishman

div.head: African Tribes
div.p: When marking up an African tribal name, use the term element with the type attribute with a value of "tribe". I saw the Nyamwezi
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Religious Faith
div.p: Use the term element with a type attribute with a value of "faith" to mark instances in the text where religious faith or an organized religion is cited. Christianity and Islam Christian values
However, for practitioners of particular faiths, see .

div.head: Occupation
div.p: Use the term element with a type attribute with a value of "occupation" anytime an occupation of any sort is mentioned in the text. Livingstone was a missionary, geographer, and abolitionist

div.head: Medical Terms
div.p: When marking up a medical reference or term, use term plus the type attribute and appropriate value, such as "ailment" or medicament". I had malaria for a month.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Organizations and Other Groups
div.p: Use the orgName element to mark instances in the text where there is mention of an organization or other type of group (or any reference to an individual as being part of a group) that is not covered by , , or . Note that all the following entities should be marked with the orgName element: African, Africans, Arab, Arabs, Boer, Boers, Christian (an individual; for use of "Christian" as an adjective, see ), Christians, Moslem (an individual; for use of "Moselm" as an adjective, see ), and Moslems. For references to organized religions (e.g., Christianity, Islam), see .
"Johanna men" and "Nassick boys" (and all variants of these two groups) to be coded as follows:
Note: All references to "slaves" and "slavery" should also be marked with orgName, as well as references to "caste", "natives", and "cannibals":
div.egXML: He had two slaves and spoke of slavery
It is believed by the natives.
div.p: Please note: Havildar and Sepoy (singular and plural) should be marked with both orgName, and term with the type attribute and a value of "occupation":
Groups relating to a specific person should also be marked with orgName:
div.egXML: from depositions of survivors of Baron's party

div.head: Bibliographical Elements
div.p: Use bibl to encode any elements of a book, including the title, that Livingstone references:

Also use bibl to encode any mention of letters or manuscripts, including Livingstone's own:
Letters from Mecca told of its coming or
he assures me that my packet of letters was not destroyed

div.head: Words in a Foreign Language
div.p:
When dealing with foreign words, there are three steps to complete:
Find the abbreviation for the foreign language at the following webpage: https://www.iana.org/assignments/language-subtag-registry/language-subtag-registry
In the header, add in a langUsage for the foreign language under the one for English as follows. Put English first, then all other languages in alphabetical order:
English Latin
Within the text, when the language comes up, you code the word/phrase as follows:
et id genus omne
Please note: The foreign tag should go outside of any other tags used relating to the word or phrase:
Pagazi

Please note: If you are unsure of the language/dialect, but know that it is not English, simply mark it as "Undetermined" using the code "und". Also, we do not tag references to languages (Spanish, French, etc.) in any way.
Definitions of the elements used above are:

div.head: Using Lists and Tables
div.p:
Use the list element to contain any lists that appear in the text. The title of any such list should be marked with the head element, while item should be used for each item within the list:
Villages:
Bambarre,
Nyangwe,
Ujiji Lists may also be broken up with line breaks (lb/)as needed:
Villages
Bambarre
Nyangwe
Ujiji
Livingstone's texts sometimes also contain tables or have information laid out in a such a way that the table format seems appropriate. Code tables and similar text (as seems appropriate -- such use may be subjective) with the table tag plus the head (for any title that the table may have), row, and cell tags.
Villages
Bambarre West of Lake Tanganyika
Nyangwe West of Lake Tanganyika
Ujiji East of Lake Tanganyika
Note: Headings, lists, items, tables, rows, and cells may all be assigned various attributes and values as relevant, as in the following example where color is marked, rows are numbered, and cells are coded for placement on the page:
Villages
Bambarre West of Lake Tanganyika
Nyangwe West of Lake Tanganyika
Ujiji East of Lake Tanganyika Note on all the above: Normally, in the examples above, the various settlements, regions, and geographical entities would be coded as per the instructions set out elsewhere in this manual. However, such coding has here been omitted for the sake of simplicity and clarity in the examples given. Additionally, in the last example, the numbering of rows is done only for illustrative purposes. Such numbering is optional and should normally not be undertaken.

div.head: Figures, Drawings, and Calculations
div.p: If you come across any figures, drawings, or calculations, please mark them with an empty figure/ element. However, you can also describe them using the figDesc element, which must then be contained by the figure element. The lion looked like this: The lion looked like this: Drawing of a lion with it's mouth open towards the viewer. The description of the figure should be short and to the point, as in the example above. In the description, you should not as a rule describe the extent of the figure (i.e, "for three lines," etc.), but rather should focus only on its content. Also, assume that phrases like "Livingstone has here..." are a given and do not need to be used explicitly.

If Livingstone has himself given the figure a title, use the head element to record this: The lion looked like this:
LionDrawing of a lion with it's mouth open towards the viewer.

If your description of the figure cites any text that Livingstone himself has provided and that text in turn can be coded, then it should be coded directly in the citation: The lion looked like this:
Lion Drawing of a lion with it's mouth open towards the viewer, with a note from Livingstone that he saw this lion "in the Kalahari."

div.head: Anything Unusual in the Text
div.p: If you come across anything unusal in the text that cannot be otherwise encoded, please do not mark it other than leaving a comment to alert the project team.
